headache - (10:34): the official reason for XWiki exclusion for GSoC 2010  
headache - (10:34): is that Google support XWiki in previous years  
headache - (10:34): so they give XWiki a break for one year  
headache - (10:35): I read this right now in gsoc channel  
sdumitriu - (10:35): Hi headache  
headache - (10:35): the next year they'll probably support XWiki  
headache - (10:35): also Qt was excluded  
headache - (10:35): \*is  
sdumitriu - (10:37): Who asked?  
vmassol - (10:37): headache: ok good to know. I think they should have this rule set up across the board for all projects and written down. that would help remove any negative feelings. Something like "no 2 years in a row from now on". I think they're not too good on their communications. Of course they do as they want since it's their money but still if they want to help OSS in general as they said  they should at least have clear rules  
vmassol - (10:38): (same as we publish our rules)  
headache - (10:38): sdumitriu, I am discussing about questionable org  
headache - (10:38): and provide some examples for my perception of good orgs and bad orgs  
CalebJamesDeLisl joined #xwiki at 10:38  
headache - (10:39): so I'm saying that XWiki is a good org because of the support for students and also because of good documentation  
headache - (10:39): while other orgs don't provide a single page about GSoC 2010  
headache - (10:39): and they are selected  
headache - (10:40): a channel operator explain me that XWiki isn't selected because of the support of the previous years  
headache - (10:42): I'm quoting "<danderson> they've been in GSoC and received support from Google for 5 years running"  
headache - (10:42): "<danderson> we decided to give them a break for 1 year, to give other orgs a chance"  
headache - (10:45): that's it  
sdumitriu - (10:46): So, did you find any interesting projects?  
headache - (10:46): I'm searching for now I'm following BioJava  
headache - (10:47): related to bioinformatic field I'll have a chat with a Mentor Andreas Prlic and I'll give him my cv  
headache - (10:47): and I'm following Openstreetmap  
headache - (10:48): I mailed with David Eearl discussing an idea for GSoC  
headache - (10:49): however none of those projects present XWiki activity in mailing list or irc-channel  
headache - (10:49): except Openstreetmap  
sdumitriu - (10:49): OSM is big  
headache - (10:49): but they talk about everything related to projects  
headache - (10:53): sure I have to send more emails, however I'm hoping to be selected by BioJava but I prefer to have 2 or 3 possibilities  
sdumitriu - (10:54): Good luck  
sdumitriu - (10:54): And we'll be here if you want to do something fun after GSoC ;)  
headache - (10:55): yeah I need luck after various problems with my professors  
headache - (10:55): sdumitriu, If I'll be not selected sure I'll consider XWiki  
headache - (10:57): it's not about money, it's all about learning  
headache - (10:57): :)

headache - (15:26): I'don't know if is Dell who produce crap notebook or Java that would kill note's cpu  
headache - (15:26): it's the 2nd automatic reboot  
headache - (15:26): :(  
lucaa - (15:30): headache: automatic reboot? that sounds like a hw problem... as in overheated machine. Check that your ventilators are working right...  
lucaa - (15:31): any program can virtually "kill" your CPU (as in sending it to 100%) but hw should take it well...  
headache - (15:33): well fan makes a lot of noise  
headache - (15:33): especially for an ant make  
lucaa - (15:33): which means it's moving, that's a good sign :)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:33): If you're on Linux, is it a hard reboot (think hardware) or a "this system is going down for a reboot NOW!" reboot, look for a miscreant program calling /usr/bin/reboot  
headache - (15:34): hardware reboot to preserve cpu I think  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:34): Looks like a heat issue.  
headache - (15:34): however this happen also with flash when watching something on megavideo  
headache - (15:34): yep  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:34): Linux?  
headache - (15:34): yes  
lucaa - (15:36): could also be failing memory (RAM)? I haven't gone through this before so I wouldn't know how it reacts, i'm just throwing ideas  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:36): Check out lm-sensors, it's a pain to install but I have a number on the panel telling the processor temp.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:36): (Might be easier with ubuntu)  
headache - (15:37): I'm installing right now  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:37): Just as I was typing my screen kicked out and I was like "WHAT??!! mine too?" (my monitor button sticks)  
headache - (15:39): :|  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:39): So lm-sensors installed? You also need sensors-applet.  
headache - (15:40): yeah I've added to panel  
headache - (15:40): 2 applet one for cpu  
headache - (15:41): I've got a dual core  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:41): So is it showing real numbers or like -1000? (not configured yet)  
headache - (15:41): I think real numbers I select percentage view  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:43): So you have a Fahrenheit or Celsius number?  
headache - (15:44): no it's show cpu usage  
headache - (15:44): maybe i take wrong applet  
headache - (15:45): well now I've found correct package  
DV left at 15:49 (Ping timeout: 276 seconds  
DV joined #xwiki at 15:51  
headache left at 15:53 (Quit: reboot  
xenon75 left at 15:57 (Ping timeout: 258 seconds  
headache joined #xwiki at 15:58  
xenon75 joined #xwiki at 15:58  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:00): Got the temp sensor working?  
headache - (16:02): yes  
headache - (16:02): 45 Celsius  
headache - (16:02): for hd and 43 for cpus  
nickless - (16:05): headache, look at /var/log/messages, maybe there are some warnings just before reboot  
xenon75 left at 16:05 (Read error: Connection reset by peer  
headache - (16:05): ok  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:05): Good point about messages, those temp numbers look ok to me.  
xenon75 joined #xwiki at 16:06  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:06): (I noticed on some of these new computers cpu temp will go through the roof when it's loaded though)  
headache - (16:07): "CE: hpet increasing min\_delta\_ns to 33750 nsec"  
headache - (16:08): one of the last messages after reboot  
sdumitriu - (16:08): That's normal  
headache - (16:09): maybe that's not a log because before I have no "coretemp" module loaded  
headache - (16:10): well it's strange now fan noise is reduced  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:11): Has the fan been louder lately than when it was new?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:11): (I have a laptop with a fan that wobbles, makes a racket and doesn't spin fast enough)  
headache - (16:12): I don't remember well but I think yes because a year ago, never happen a suddenly halt  
headache - (16:13): a sudden shutdown  
sdumitriu - (16:13): Hm, I once had a problem with a laptop, the kernel was generating CPU temp messages which weren't consumed, and the fan speed regulating module was blocked until those messages were consumed  
headache - (16:13): with black screen all off  
headache - (16:13): but this happen also with windows 7  
sdumitriu - (16:13): So the fan didn't run until the temperature reached the critical 95C  
nickless - (16:14): maybe you just need to clean it from dust a bit  
sdumitriu - (16:14): The problem was fixed by making gkrellm run at startup  
sdumitriu - (16:14): headache: What CPU is it?  
headache - (16:14): T5800  
headache - (16:15): it's a dell studio 1535  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:15): I read that new intels scale back to prevent overheat but in any case, the intel spec sheet on their 2.6Ghz duel core says 170F so about 70C is the limit.  
headache - (16:16): however after enabling coretemp module the fan noise is reduced  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:18): You could start loading it and if the number goes way up then you know you need to do something about the heat.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:19): (You have the number in the panel changing in real time right?)  
headache - (16:19): yes  
headache - (16:21): I have 2 tiny books I put them down the base of notebook to improve air circulation  
headache - (16:21): :-D  
bblfish - (16:21): @timoreilly twitters on foaf+ssl http://twitter.com/timoreilly/status/10823135667  
bblfish - (16:21): with a bit of luck he may try xwiki :-)  
lucaa - (16:23): oh yeah!  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:24): "Have to start from the UX end." I wonder what the best UX would be. Remembering which key you use with a given site?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:24): Firefox password remembering feature seems like the right idea.  
DV left at 16:26 (Read error: Connection reset by peer  
bblfish - (16:27): I am not sure he tried it completely  
DV joined #xwiki at 16:27  
bblfish - (16:27): he did not make an account on webid.myxwiki  
bblfish - (16:27): he may have tried foaf.me, and they need to work on their UI  
bblfish - (16:27): (in fact they are, and should have a big upgrade soon)  
bblfish - (16:28): That is why I did webid.myx… because foaf.me was a bit slow on the ui  
headache - (16:29): I wonder foaf is like an identity card ? I am bit scared...  
bblfish - (16:29): it's a self signed identity card  
bblfish - (16:29): :-)  
bblfish - (16:29): you make claims about yourself  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:30): headache: That was my first reaction too, the answer is it doesn't have to be.  
headache - (16:30): so government could track down my relationships  
bblfish - (16:30): you can allow only your friends to see those  
bblfish - (16:31): we don't have an implementation yet, because it is a bit more complex to do  
bblfish - (16:31): and we are trying to get the basics  
bblfish - (16:31): sorted  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:31): It doesn't really help the govt because it isn't issued by the govt.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:32): (Unless you get a key at a gov website)  
bblfish - (16:32): Got to webid.my… you can claim your spirderman :-)  
headache - (16:32): I understand thanks  
headache - (16:32): facebook does this  
bblfish - (16:33): yes, but with FB there is a third party: FB  
headache - (16:33): but takes data and use it for private interest  
bblfish - (16:33): who sees everything  
bblfish - (16:33): yep  
headache - (16:33): so there is no risk that someone take my email for example  
headache - (16:33): or could take my identity  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:34): With foafssl if FB or whoever is being a pain, you can take your keys (and your friends) somewhere else.  
headache - (16:34): and make something dangerous  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:34): re take your email: With passwords the password is passed plaintext over the line.  
headache - (16:35): it's encrypted no?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:35): No not unless the site has https:  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:36): if it's just an http site (almost all) then it's plaintext.  
DV left at 16:36 (Ping timeout: 276 seconds  
headache - (16:36): well I usually send email through gmail and it uses https  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:37): gmail is pretty secure but then you are giving your info to the googlemonster.  
headache - (16:37): ehehehe  
headache - (16:37): there's always something to pay for  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:38): There are some smaller free email services with ssl.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:40): Anyway ReddiDigBookWitterSpace doesn't use ssl so those passwords are plain.  
headache - (16:41): fantastic  
headache - (16:41): ReddiDigBooWitterSpace ahahahahah :D  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:42): What's cool about foafssl is that you generate a private key which never leaves your disk.  
headache - (16:43): it's interesting anyway  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:43): The public key goes to the site and when you want to log in you send a signed timestamp telling the site that you belong to that public key and it can let you in.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:44): Anyone can read your message but nobody can modify it.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:44): And they can't replay it because of the timestamp.  
headache - (16:44): what is a signed timestamp?  
headache - (16:45): it's something related to private key  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:45): You send the exact time and sign over that with your key.  
headache - (16:46): So cannot exist another timestamp because there's only one in a given time  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:46): Until like 50 years from now :)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:47): So if someone attempts a "man in the middle" attack, you will not be able to log in or will end up logged in as the wrong user.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:48): (Obvious)  
headache - (16:50): cool  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:50): It can be if we make it.  
headache - (16:53): it will be integrated in XWiki?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:56): Yes it will.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:56): We are facing a problem though.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:57): In order to encrypt the connection to a website the site needs a key (because Firefox says so)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:58): Also the key needs to be signed by one of the certificate authorities which are included in Firefox.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (16:59): These people charge lots of money to sign a key which is one of the reasons why we don't see more https on hobbiest's sites.  
headache - (17:00): :|  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:00): But with the right amount of money paid to the right people you can get anything signed which is a huge security problem.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:01): So we have a few options.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:01): 1. We get a few sites signed like https://www.foafssl.org and all requests get bounced off of those sites.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:02): Advantage: It's easy for the sysops and the users.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:02): Disadvantage: After login, the connection drops back down to plain old http.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:03): (This is implemented now.)  
bblfish - (17:04): yes, then long term, we find a solution so you don't need foafssl.org  
bblfish - (17:05): (we know you don't in fact need it) it's just to find a solution to make it really easy not to need foafssl.org :-)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:06): 2. Everybody gets a signed key for their website. Dnssec will make this easier but we still have to jump through hoops for semi redundant encryption which uses a broken model (you can get any key with enough money).  
bblfish - (17:07): ( ah sorry, you had not finsihed. For example https://openid4.me/simpleLogin.php does not use foafssl.org - you need a webid before trying it )  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:07): Note: dnssec will improve the "any key with enough money" problem but AFAIK we still have to trust some guy with a "key to the internet".  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:09): bblfish: Do you know if the Kaminsky bug is actually fixed with dnssec assuming a root key were to leak out?  
bblfish - (17:09): yes, though I can imagine with time that guy being in the UN, or them finding a way to have N <10 top guys  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:10): Nah  it'll be George W Bush who holds the key.  
headache - (17:10): ahahahahaa  
bblfish - (17:10): Interesting, I don't know what happens in that case.  
bblfish - (17:10): It is also possible to make hardware that contains the key in wrote only mode  
bblfish - (17:10): or even write once, never see again  
bblfish - (17:11): s/wrote/write/  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:11): (Human nature means the worst people try to get the positions of highest trust.)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:12): Someone needs the key to delegate the root zones, add zones etc. It should be as secure as old dns even if the keys are leaked.  
bblfish - (17:12): there is a long wikipedia article on it  
bblfish - (17:12): I think it's hierarchical  
bblfish - (17:12): They had a problem with the first version I think due to the issue you mention  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:13): Even with fancy keys, the routers should know that .org is not hosted out of a laptop in a coffee shop.  
bblfish - (17:15): :D  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:15): Anyway foafssl...   Option 2 is already implemented, that's how foafssl.org works.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:15): Option 3 is the clients download an addon and validate the servers using foaf.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:16): (Not implemented)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:16): But it's relatively easy to do.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:17): I like 3 a lot because it provides 2 levels of trust (You can't middleman because you don't have the client key and you can't middleman because you don't have the server key.)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:18): Another feature which is sadly missing from Firefox is storing of good keys.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:19): If I go to bank.com today, and I go to bank.com tomorrow and suddenly the key is different and is signed by some obscure CA nobody knows about, I want to know.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:19): Currently you would get no notice about such an event.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:19): The key is signed by a CA which is installed in Firefox, it \_must\_ be good.  
headache - (17:22): do you study these things a lot? :)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:22): I sit and think about it.  
headache - (17:23): I'm in the first phase "I sit"  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:23): Back in the day I used to read textfiles from sites which would use ssl but didn't bother to get their keys signed.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:23): Nobody cared about security, they used ssl just to be cool.  
npm joined #xwiki at 17:24  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:24): The browser would always say "this site isn't trusted" and I always clicked ok and wasn't bothered anymore for the day.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:25): With the advent of Firefox3 they put this cop in your way who says "You shal not pass!"  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:26): If you're on firefox, you can see him here https://svn.xwiki.org  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:27): I suspect the CA lobby, after all what CA would like the idea of self signed keys?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:32): So short story is CA don't really protect us, they make website owners pay money and they make it a pain to look at websites which use https and don't pay them.  
xenon751 joined #xwiki at 17:36  
xenon75 left at 17:36 (Read error: Connection reset by peer  
headache - (17:44): On tuesday I'll have an interview with Andreas Prlic BioJava's project lead http://biojava.org/wiki/Google\_Summer\_of\_Code  
headache - (17:44): some advices are welcome :)  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (17:50): I'm not the one to ask, bioinformatics concerns me for the reason foaf concerns you :)  
headache - (17:53): CalebJamesDeLisl, bioinformatics is not my field but someone tell me that it's not a big deal  
headache - (17:53): general advices about interview  
xenon75 joined #xwiki at 18:08  
xenon751 left at 18:08 (Read error: Connection reset by peer  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:09): Ask lots of questions. Your interest in the field is more important than your skill.  
headache - (18:09): CalebJamesDeLisl, fantastic advice :))  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:11): I would ask then how the technology will be guided so it cannot be turned toward making weapons, (that's just me)  
headache - (18:13): :D  
xenon751 joined #xwiki at 18:13  
xenon75 left at 18:13 (Read error: Connection reset by peer  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:13): If they are thinking about their field, they will be happy and they will remember your interview as a good experience.  
sdumitriu - (18:17): headache: How much experience do you have with bioinformatics algorithms?  
headache - (18:17): CalebJamesDeLisl, do you study social interactions/relations or have you read How to win friends and influence people by Dale Carnegie?  
headache - (18:17): sdumitriu, I need to study something before interview  
headache - (18:18): also about dynamic programming I take some slides and material by Steven Skiena  
sdumitriu - (18:18): For the basics, if you understand dynamic programming you should be ok  
headache - (18:20): just to have a good idea, but I think he could ask me something related to Java or Junit because I said to him that I know them.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:21): headache: No I have heard about the book but I haven't read it. I just like debate and problem solving, everything else followed.  
headache - (18:22): CalebJamesDeLisl, what you said about questions and interest recalls something that is written in that book  
headache - (18:22): :D  
headache - (18:23): it's a good book anyway there are a lot of good advices about human relations and how to solve problems in real life well social problem not foaf  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:23): Dale Carnegie. Hmm, he even steals my ideas.  
xenon75 joined #xwiki at 18:23  
xenon751 left at 18:23 (Read error: Connection reset by peer  
headache - (18:24): CalebJamesDeLisl, if you are interested http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How\_to\_Win\_Friends\_and\_Influence\_People  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:25): The title reads like it's something sneaky.  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:25): (Judge a book by it's cover...)  
headache - (18:25): well it's a collection of stories  
headache - (18:25): where the author shows how to overtake some social problems  
headache - (18:26): it's very old 1937 or later  
headache - (18:26): Don't criticize  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:27): I prefer to imagine that we all have the same point of view and we are just confused by assumptions which we don't know we are making.  
headache - (18:27): it's one thing that I forget easily  
headache - (18:27): ahahhah hilarious  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:28): (It is easy to see this living in a place where half the people vote for one crook and the other half vote for another)  
headache - (18:29): LOL  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:29): \* This is of course a hypothetical place and any similarity to real life events is purely coincidental :)  
headache - (18:29): CalebJamesDeLisl, you're lucky  
headache - (18:29): you don't live in Italy  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:30): tpb still blocked?  
headache - (18:30): tpb what does it mean?  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (18:30): google it :)  
headache - (18:30): naaa  
headache - (18:31): it's more dangerous, it's a treat to democracy and free information
